concept.title: Information in multiple languages
concept.shortdesc: Use a mirrored architecture for localised DITA content.

conbody.p: Translated DITA topics should be stored in a parallel, mirrored folder structure, with the same file names as the original language source.

lq.reftitle: Troy Klukewich, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p: In the last three organizations I've worked at, translated content and the source English were all stored in separate, parallel folders.

One factor to consider is scalability and logistics of translations/ localizations. As more languages are added, it is likely that multiple vendors will be involved in translations. Plus, I wouldn't ever want 25 to 40 languages all stored in the same file.

Using a mirrored architecture, you can send off separate file packages for translation to multiple vendors at the same time for simultaneous translations. If translations are stored in the same file, a change in one translated section would trigger a diff for another vendor analyzing the file. Even if no translation is involved with the bogus diff (say in a formerly translated section), the analysis overhead adds up and there is an accumulated charge.

I don't see how the translation logistics would be handled in a single file and I wouldn't want to figure it out. :-) Vendors I've worked with only want to see the source language (English in my case) in the files to be translated. Keep it clean and simple.
In short, mirrored architecture is a standard approach for projects with multiple translations.
